review.title: Decomposable Submodular Function Minimization: Discrete and Continuous
review.abstract: This paper investigates connections between discrete and continuous approaches for decomposable submodular function minimization. We provide improved running time estimates for the state-of-the-art continuous algorithms for the problem using combinatorial arguments. We also provide a systematic experimental comparison of the two types of methods, based on a clear distinction between level-0 and level-1 algorithms.

metadata.title: Decomposable Submodular Function Minimization: Discrete and Continuous

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 3.01 830v 1 [cs.L G] 6M arThis paper examines relationships between discrete and continuous approaches to minimize submodular functions. We provide improved runtime estimates for state-of-the-art continuous algorithms for the problem with combinatorial arguments. We also provide a systematic experimental comparison of the two methods based on a clear distinction between Level 0 and Level 1 algorithms.

sections.heading: 1.1 Prior work
sections.text: CRC has a long history in combinatorial optimization since the early 1970s, following the influential work of Edmonds [Edm70]. The first polynomial-time algorithms were obtained via the ellipsoid method [GLS81]; recent work has significantly improved this approach [LSW15]. Substantial work on the design of strongly polynomial-combinatorial algorithms [Sch00, IFF01, Iwa03, Orl09] has been achieved.

sections.text: The work [ABKM12, FJMPZ13] uses a brute force search as a subroutine for any FI with a runtime of 2 | Ci | EOi. However, this is only applicable for small Ci's and is not suitable for our experiments where the maximum clique size is quite large. As a general-purpose algorithm, we used the Fujishige-Wolfe minimum standardization point algorithm [FI11, Wol76]. We provide improved running time estimates for the state-of-the-art continuous algorithms for the problem using combinatorial arguments. We also provide a systematic experimental comparison of the two types of methods, based on a clear distinction between level-0 and level-1 algorithms.
